meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! It's your boy back at it again with another groovy review that's sure to get the party started! Today, I'm diving into the wild world of The LEGO Movie 2 Videogame, where everything is supposed to be awesome... or so they claim.

Let me start by saying that I went in with relatively low expectations. I mean, movie tie-ins can be a real hit-or-miss affair, and this one didn't exactly get off on the right foot (see what I did there?). But hey, I'm always down to give games a chance, and who knows? Maybe this little guy would surprise me.

Unfortunately, my expectations were mostly met. The game's visuals are... well, let's just say they're not exactly going to win any awards for originality or graphical fidelity. It looks like someone took the LEGO Movie 2 movie's aesthetic and slapped it onto a generic LEGO Worlds reskin (ahem, I see what those other critics did there too). The environments feel stale, the character models are wonky, and don't even get me started on the lack of humor and charm that made the actual movie so delightful.

But hey, maybe the gameplay would make up for it? Unfortunately, nope. It's all pretty standard fare – build, explore, collect studs – with some annoyingly clunky co-op mechanics to boot. I mean, who thought it was a good idea to make two players control separate characters on screen, only to have them get stuck in an infinite loop of "my character's not doing what I want!"? Yeah, that's exactly the kind of thing you want from your LEGO game: frustration and boredom.

Now, I know some of my fellow critics might say, "Ah, but this is a game for kids! It's meant to be simple and fun!" And to that, I say... baloney! If it's not good enough for adults (ahem, like me), then it's just not good enough. Kids deserve better than a lazy cash-grab like this.

So what's my final verdict? Well, let's just say it's not exactly "everything is awesome"... but hey, maybe that's the point? After all, isn't the LEGO franchise all about embracing your inner child and having fun with simple things? If so, then I guess The LEGO Movie 2 Videogame might still have its charm... for the youngin's. For everyone else? Meh, it's a skip.

That's it for this groovy review, folks! Tune in next time when I'll be covering another thrilling topic – probably something about video games, maybe some movies or TV shows, and definitely more of my witty banter!
